Department of Chemistry, School of Science, Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China This work presents a novel and recyclable tetramethylguanidine-modified polyacrylonitrile fiber catalyst (PANMGF), specifically designed for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction, which is a crucial method in organic synthesis for CC bond formation. The PANMGF was characterized through Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), elemental analysis (EA), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and mechanical performance analysis. These results collectively confirmed the successful grafting of dimethylcyanamide as a guanidine precursor, which was subsequently converted into tetramethylguanidine functionalities on the PANMGF. Under mild conditions of 40 °C with H2O as the solvent for a 12-hour reaction, the PANMGF exhibited superior catalytic performance, with a yield of 97 %. A thorough investigation of various benzaldehyde substrates revealed yields exceeding 90 % for both electron-withdrawing and electron-donating derivatives. These results demonstrate the remarkable substrate versatility and broad applicability of this catalyst. Moreover, when applied to other active methylene substrates, such as methyl cyanoacetate and malononitrile, the PANMGF achieved yields of 97 % and 98 %, respectively. These results collectively underscore its broad substrate scope across 28 different substrates and exceptional stability, which maintained a yield of 91.1 % even after 14 cycles, with an 89.9 % yield observed in the 15th cycle. Additionally, gram-scale experiments yielded a high separation efficiency of 93.6 %, further reinforcing the significant potential of PANMGF for practical applications in sustainable organic synthesis. Graphical Abstract Keywords Polyacrylonitrile fiber Tetramethylguanidine-modified Knoevenagel condensation Broad substrate scope Recyclability Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Green chemistry [1–3] has emerged as a cornerstone of modern chemical research to achieve the global goal of sustainability [4,5]. By minimizing environmental pollution [6,7] and improving resource efficiency [8], green chemistry drives the development of eco-friendly catalytic systems [9,10]. The Knoevenagel condensation [11,12], a classic pivotal method for CC bond formation, plays a critical role in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, fragrances, dyes, and polymers [13–15]. Its effective implementation is crucial for both organic synthesis and the advancement of functional materials [16,17]. Consequently, the development of green, efficient, and recyclable catalytic systems to enhance the sustainability of Knoevenagel condensation reactions has become a major research topic [18–21]. Traditional Knoevenagel condensation reactions typically rely on homogeneous catalysts [22,23] or noble-metal-based systems [24]. Although these catalysts often demonstrate high catalytic activity, they suffer from several inherent limitations too, such as difficulties in separation, catalyst deactivation, and environmental toxicity, which constrain their widespread industrial applications [25,26]. Additionally, the poor recyclability of homogeneous catalysts results in low utilization, increasing both the cost and environmental burden [27,28]. Therefore, the development of efficient, recyclable, and environmentally benign heterogeneous catalytic systems [29,30] is crucial for enhancing the practical application of Knoevenagel condensation reactions [31–34]. Polyacrylonitrile fiber (PANF), with their superior mechanical properties, chemical stability, and ease of surface modification, are being increasingly recognized as ideal heterogeneous catalysts[35–38]. Surface functionalization of PANF enables the incorporation of specific catalytic sites while maintaining the structural integrity and stability of the material [39–41]. Moreover, they offer excellent recyclability, delivering consistent catalytic activity across multiple cycles, in alignment with the principles of green chemistry [42,43]. Our recent studies have demonstrated the successful application of modified PANF in diverse fields, including rapid detection and adsorption of heavy metals [44–46], removal of aqueous pollutants [47,48], and heterogeneous catalysis in various organic transformations [49–53]. These properties highlight the great potential of functionalized PANF-based catalysts for advancing sustainable catalysis and environmental applications. Guanylate compounds [54,55] are a class of highly effective basic organic catalysts that, owing to their unique basicity and ability to form hydrogen bonds, often exhibit superior catalytic performance to those demonstrated by conventional organic and inorganic bases [56,57]. Incorporating guanylate functionalities onto PANF not only enhances their catalytic performance, but also significantly improves their stability and recyclability in aqueous media [58,59]. In this paper, we report the design and synthesis of guanylate-functionalized PANF catalysts (PANGF and PANMGF) via a facile hydrothermal strategy tailored for aqueous-phase Knoevenagel condensation reactions, as shown in Scheme 1. The resulting catalyst exhibits superior catalytic efficiency and delivers high product yields with excellent recyclability, highlighting its potential in sustainable and environmentally benign organic synthesis. 2 Material and methods Reagents and instruments used in the present work are listed in Section 1 of the Supporting Information. 2.1 Preparation of trimethylguanidine-modified polyacrylonitrile fiber (PANGF) To a 100-mL round-bottom flask with a reflux condenser, 40.0 mL of 1,3-diaminopropane and 20.0 mL of distilled water were added. Dry PANF (2.00 g) was introduced, and the mixture was heated to reflux for 1 h. Upon completion of the reaction, the fiber was removed, washed with distilled water at 60–70 °C, and dried in an oven at 60 °C for 12 h to obtain 1,3-diaminopropane-functionalized fiber (PANPAF). To a separate 50-mL round-bottom flask equipped with a reflux condenser under a nitrogen atmosphere, 25 mL of dimethylcyanamide and 1.0 g of dried PANPAF fiber were added. The mixture was heated to reflux for 12 h. Upon completion of the reaction, the fiber was collected and washed by ethanol at 60–70 °C. The washed fiber was then dried in an oven at 60 °C for 12 h to obtain trimethylguanidine-functionalized fiber (PANGF). The functionality of PANPAF was calculated using the formula: functionality = (m2-m1)× 1000/((M+1)×m1, where m1 and m2 represent the masses of PANF and PANPAF, respectively, and (M+1) denotes the molecular weight of the introduced functional group. The functionality of PANGF was calculated using the formula: functionality = (m4-m2)× 1000/((M+1)×m2, where m2 and m4 represent the masses of PANPAF and PANGF, respectively. 2.2 Preparation of tetramethylguanidine-modified polyacrylonitrile fiber (PANMGF) To a 100-mL round-bottom flask equipped with a reflux condenser, 40.0 mL of N-methyl-1,3-diaminopropane and 20.0 mL of distilled water were added. Dry PANF (2.00 g) was introduced, and the mixture was heated to reflux for 2.5 h. After completion of the reaction, the fiber was removed, extensively washed with distilled water at 60–70 °C, and dried in an oven at 60 °C for 12 h, yielding N-methyl-1,3-diaminopropane-functionalized polyacrylonitrile fiber (PANMPAF). To a separate 50-mL round-bottom flask under a nitrogen atmosphere, 25 mL of dimethylcyanamide and 1.0 g of dried PANMPAF fiber were added. The mixture was then heated to reflux for 12 h. Upon completion, the fiber was retrieved, thoroughly washed with ethanol at 60–70 °C, and dried in an oven at 60 °C for 12 h to obtain tetramethylguanidine-functionalized fiber (PANMGF). The functionality of PANM PAF was calculated using the formula: functionality = (m3-m1)× 1000/((M+1)×m1, where m1 and m3 represent the masses of PANF and PANMPAF, respectively, and (M+1) denotes the molecular weight of the introduced functional group. The functionality of PANMGF was calculated as: functionality = (m5-m3)× 1000/((M+1)×m3, where m3 and m5 represent the masses of PANMPAF and PANMGF, respectively. 2.3 Experimental procedure for knoevenagel condensation reaction To a 15-mL dried pressure-resistant tube, benzaldehyde (1 mmol), ethyl cyanoacetate (1.1 mmol), 8 mol% PANMGF or PANGF, and water (2 mL) were sequentially added. The reaction mixture was heated to 40 °C and stirred for 12 h. After completion, the reaction system was cooled to room temperature, and the fiber was recovered by filtration and washed with ethyl acetate. The resulting reaction mixture was then extracted with ethyl acetate (10 mL×3), and the combined organic layers were concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by column chromatography (petroleum ether: acetate = 10:1) to obtain the desired product in isolated yields. 2.4 Gram-scale experiment To a 50-mL dry round-bottom flask, benzaldehyde (10 mmol), ethyl cyanoacetate (11 mmol), 8 mol% PANMGF, and H2O (20 mL) were sequentially added. The mixture was heated to 40 °C and stirred for 12 h. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was cooled, and the fiber was removed and washed with ethyl acetate. The reaction mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 10 mL), and the combined organic layers were concentrated under reduced pressure. The resulting crude product was purified using column chromatography (petroleum ether: acetate = 10:1) to afford the desired product in isolated yields. 2.5 Recycling performance experiments To a 15-mL oven-dried, pressure-resistant tube, benzaldehyde (1 mmol), ethyl cyanoacetate (1.1 mmol), 8 mol% PANMGF, and H2O (2 mL) were sequentially added. The mixture was heated to 40 °C and stirred for 12 h. Upon completion, the reaction system was cooled to room temperature, and the fiber was recovered by filtration, thoroughly washed with ethyl acetate, and dried overnight at 60 °C for reuse in subsequent catalytic cycles. The reaction mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (10 mL×3), and the combined organic layers were concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified using column chromatography (petroleum ether: acetate = 10:1) to yield the desired product. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Optimization of PANMGF preparation Catalysts with high functionality typically exhibit a high density of active sites, which enhances their substrate adsorption and catalytic activity. For PANMGF, the degree of functionalization is strongly dependent on the reaction time. To optimize the functional group density of the PANMGF catalyst, the impact of the reaction time on fiber modification was systematically evaluated, as shown in Fig. 1. At a constant modification temperature of 105 °C, increasing the reaction time from 6 to 12 h led to a significant enhancement in functional group loading, which increased from 0.49 to 1.23 mmol/g, respectively. The optimal functionalization was achieved at 12 h, which indicated that prolonged reaction times promote the generation of additional active sites and enhance surface modification. Notably, the most substantial increase occurred between 9 and 12 h, during which the functional group loading more than doubled, indicating that 12 h was the optimal reaction period. However, extending the reaction time beyond 12 h resulted in a decline in functional group loading, likely due to overfunctionalization or surface degradation. Therefore, a 12-hour reaction time was identified as the optimal condition for guanidine-functionalized fiber, providing a balance between maximizing the functional group density and maintaining the structural integrity of the fiber, both of which are critical for achieving superior catalytic performance. 3.2 Characterization 3.2.1 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) As shown in Fig. 2, PANF, which is characterized by a high density of cyano groups (-CN) and a smaller amount of ester groups (-COOCH₃), exhibit prominent absorption peaks at 2243 and 1733 cm⁻¹ , corresponding to the stretching vibrations of the CN and CO bonds, respectively. After amine molecules were incorporated onto the PANF, a decrease in the relative intensity of the CN peak at 2243 cm−1 was observed, indicating that some cyano groups participated in the grafting reaction. Primary and secondary amines typically display N–H stretching vibrations within the 3300–3500 cm−1 range, often accompanied by N–H bending vibrations in the 1500–1600 cm−1 region (Fig. 2, PANPAF and PANMPAF). These vibrations reflect the successful attachment of the amine functional groups onto the fiber framework. Additionally, the introduction of amine groups may facilitate hydrogen bond formation, resulting in the broadening of the absorption bands, particularly in the N–H stretching region. This broadening is a characteristic feature of hydrogen-bonded systems, which further confirms the successful integration of amine functionalities into the polymer structure. After the incorporation of dimethylcyanamide onto the PANPAF and PANMPAF, the formation of guanidine groups (CN) resulted in new absorption peaks at 1562.9 and 1668.6 cm⁻¹ , corresponding to the stretching vibrations of the CN bonds. Additionally, new absorption features at approximately 730.4 and 879.5 cm⁻¹ were detected, which were attributed to the out-of-plane bending vibrations of -NH- groups in the guanidine -CNH- structure. These findings confirm the successful incorporation of guanidine groups and effective modification of the PANF. 3.2.2 Elemental analysis (EA) As shown in Table 1, after the modification of PANF with amine molecules, some of the cyano groups (-CN) on the PANF reacted with the amine molecules. Compared to the original fiber structure, amine molecules typically contain fewer carbon atoms and more hydrogen atoms, resulting in a decrease in the carbon (C) and nitrogen (N) content, along with an increase in the hydrogen (H) content (Table 1, entries 1, 2, and 4). This reduction in the C and N contents, accompanied by an increase in the H content, confirms the successful preparation of two types of amine-modified fibers (PANPAF and PANMPAF). Subsequent incorporation of dimethyl cyanamide into PANPAF and PANMPAF led to a further decrease in the carbon (C) content, which can be attributed to the introduction of guanidine groups. The guanidine groups, characterized by a higher nitrogen-to-carbon ratio, contain fewer carbon atoms, thus causing an overall reduction in the carbon (C) content and a corresponding increase in the nitrogen (N) content within PANGF and PANMGF, along with a decrease in hydrogen (H) content (Table 1, entries 2, 3, 4, and 5). These changes in the elemental distribution further confirm the successful functionalization of the fiber with guanidine groups. The elemental composition of PANMGF after 15 catalytic cycles (PANMGF-15) remains largely unchanged compared to that of the freshly prepared PANMGF, indicating the stability of the catalyst over repeated cycles. 3.2.3 X-ray diffraction (XRD) In the XRD analysis presented in Fig. 3, the peak at 17.0° is associated with the (1 0 0) crystal plane of PANF, while the peak at 29.5° corresponds to the (1 1 0) crystal plane. Although the intensities of these peaks diminish in the amine-modified PANPAF and PANMPAF, the fundamental crystal planes of the original PANF structure remain evident. In contrast, guanidine-functionalized PANGF and PANMGF show a more pronounced reduction in the peak intensity than PANPAF and PANMPAF. Nonetheless, the characteristic crystal planes of the PANF are still preserved. These XRD results further confirm the successful functionalization of the fiber with guanidine groups while maintaining a substantial degree of structural integrity. 3.2.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) As depicted in Fig. 4a, the XPS analysis reveals a pronounced increase in the intensity of the N 1 s peak for the guanidine-functionalized fiber (PANGF and PANMGF). This significant enhancement underscores the effective incorporation of the guanidine groups into the fiber structure. The introduction of guanidine groups results in the formation of a new bonding configuration, –CNH, which is evident from the N 1 s spectra of PANGF and PANMGF (Fig. 4c and d). This is indicated by the emergence of an additional peak and a shift in the overall peak position toward a higher binding energy (Fig. 4b, c, and d). The observed shift suggests a notable alteration in the chemical environment of the nitrogen atoms, which is likely due to the formation of a –CNH bond. Such a shift not only confirms the successful functionalization of the fiber with guanidine groups, but also highlights significant changes in the electronic environment of the nitrogen within the PANMGF. Therefore, the detailed XPS analysis provides compelling evidence for both the incorporation of guanidine and structural modifications within the fiber matrix, affirming the robustness of the functionalization process. 3.2.5 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) As illustrated in Fig. 5, SEM provides a detailed examination of the surface morphology of the fibers. The original PANF is characterized by a relatively smooth and uniform surface, as shown in Fig. 5a, b, and c. This smoothness reflects the pristine state of the fiber before modification. Upon amine modification, the surfaces of PANPAF and PANMPAF exhibit a notable increase in roughness, as shown in Fig. 5d, e, f, j, k, and l. This roughness is marked by distinct grooves and a more textured appearance, indicating the successful incorporation of amine groups into the PANF. The increased number of surface irregularities is a direct result of the introduction of amine functionalities, which disrupt the original smooth texture. Further modification with guanidine functional groups induces even more pronounced changes in the surface morphology. The PANMGF, as shown in Fig. 5m, n, and o, demonstrate a pronounced increase in surface roughness, featuring well-defined and orderly active sites. The enhanced roughness is attributed to additional guanidine groups, which result in the formation of more surface features and regularities. This phenomenon produces a more heterogeneous surface with a higher density of active sites, which is crucial for catalytic and other functional applications. Despite the surface modifications, the fibers retain their overall structural integrity, as confirmed by SEM images showing well-preserved morphology. The modifications enhance surface characteristics—such as increased roughness and the emergence of defined active sites—without compromising the mechanical framework of the fibers. This balance between structural robustness and surface activation is particularly important for applications requiring both mechanical durability and catalytic efficiency. The SEM analysis thus not only verifies the successful introduction of functional groups but also underscores their significant impact on surface morphology. The enhanced roughness and exposure of active sites are expected to play a critical role in improving catalytic performance, highlighting the effectiveness of the surface modification strategy. 3.2.6 Thermogravimetry analysis (TG) The thermal stability of PANF, PANPAF, PANGF, PANMPAF and PANMGF was evaluated via thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), as shown in Fig. 6. All samples exhibited negligible mass loss below 200 °C, suggesting good thermal stability. Compared to the pristine and intermediate fibers (PANF, PANPAF, and PANMPAF), the guanidine-functionalized fibers (PANGF and PANMGF) showed greater mass loss in the 200–450 °C range, which can be attributed to the presence of grafted dimethylcyanamide moieties and possible morphological changes introduced during the surface modification. Notably, PANMGF retained approximately 85 % of its original mass at 300 °C, ensuring its stability under the applied reaction conditions. These results collectively demonstrate the high thermal stability of PANMGF. As demonstrated by the TGA results in Fig. 6, the guanidine-functionalized fibers, especially PANMGF, exhibit significant thermal decomposition above 250 °C. This decomposition is primarily attributed to the breakdown of grafted dimethylcyanamide groups and structural changes in the fiber matrix. Therefore, extending the CO₂-TPD measurement beyond 250 °C would result in overlapping signals from fiber degradation, rendering the data unreliable for meaningful analysis. Notably, the CO₂-TPD data collected up to 250 °C effectively reflect the desorption behavior of the basic sites. To maintain clarity and logical coherence within the main text, the complete TPD-CO₂ spectra and detailed analysis of surface basicity are provided in Section 3 of the Supporting Information. 3.2.7 Mechanical strength analysis Mechanical strength is an important measure of fiber performance, especially when assessing how well fiber can endure repeated use in practical applications. The breaking strength (BS) represents the absolute tensile strength of the fiber, while the retention of breaking strength (RBS) quantifies the percentage of the original strength retained following chemical modification. As shown in Table 2, after amine modification, the BS of the PANMPAF decreased to 8.66 cN, with an RBS of 92 %, showing only a small reduction in strength. Further modification with guanidine groups slightly lowered the BS of the PANMGF to 7.89 cN, with an RBS of 84 %. These results suggest that the fibers remained structurally strong even after modification, making them suitable for practical applications. 3.3 Comparison of catalytic performance and selection of the optimal catalyst The catalytic performance of the synthesized fiber-based catalysts was systematically evaluated using ethyl cyanoacetate and benzaldehyde as model substrates under the same reaction conditions (8 mol% catalyst loading, 40 °C, 12 h, H₂O or CH3OH as the solvent). The results are shown in Fig. 7. In the presence of H₂O as the solvent and in the absence of any catalyst, the blank reaction proceeded with a low yield of 13 %, and the unmodified PANF failed to improve the yield, confirming that the PANF lacks the necessary active sites for catalysis. The modification of PANF with 1,3-diaminopropane or N-methyl-1,3-diaminopropane increased the yield to 31 % and 36 %, respectively. This improvement demonstrates that the basic functional groups can effectively promote the Knoevenagel condensation reaction. PANGF and PANMGF catalysts, modified with trimethylguanidine and tetramethylguanidine, respectively, showed significant improvements in catalytic performance. Notably, PANMGF, which exhibits the strongest basicity, achieved a high yield of 97 %. Furthermore, when the reaction was conducted in organic solvents, such as CH3OH, PANMGF still exhibited the highest catalytic efficiency, achieving a yield of 99 %. This enhanced performance can be attributed to the strong basicity of tetramethylguanidine, which effectively promotes the Knoevenagel condensation. Given its superior catalytic activity, the PANMGF was selected for further optimization of the reaction conditions in the Knoevenagel condensation reaction to maximize its efficiency and explore its broader applicability. 3.4 Optimization for knoevenagel condensation reaction After identifying the PANMGF as the optimal catalyst for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction, the reaction conditions were systematically optimized to achieve maximum efficiency, as summarized in Table 3. First, solvent screening was conducted to evaluate the effect of solvent on the reaction (Table 3, entries 1–9). Among the solvents tested, methanol afforded the highest yield of 99 % (entry 8), which can be attributed to its excellent solubility and role as a polar protic solvent for stabilizing reactive intermediates. Acetonitrile and water also performed well, delivering yields of 92 % and 97 %, respectively (entries 6 and 9). In contrast, nonpolar and weakly polar solvents, such as ethyl acetate, tetrahydrofuran, and toluene (entries 1–5), exhibited substantially lower yields, likely because of their limited ability to facilitate the solvation of polar intermediates during the reaction. Considering both the yield and environmental sustainability, H2O was selected as the solvent of choice, which led to a comparable yield of 97 % while serving as a greener alternative to organic solvents. Building on the solvent study, we next optimized catalyst loading to achieve a balance between efficiency and economy (Table 3, entries 9–12). The results indicated that 8 mol% loading of the PANMGF provided the highest yield of 97 % (entry 9), while increasing the catalyst loading to 10 mol% (entry 12) did not offer any further improvement. Hence, it can be suggested that the catalytic sites in the PANMGF are already sufficiently active at 8 mol%, and that excess catalyst is unnecessary under the optimized conditions. Temperature screening was subsequently performed to investigate the influence of temperature on the reaction kinetics and yields (Table 3, entries 10, 13, 14, 15, 16 and 17). At a lower temperature of 25 °C (entry 13), the reaction proceeded at a slower rate, resulting in a significantly reduced yield of 54 %. The optimal temperature was determined to be 40 °C, which provided the highest yield of 97 % (entry 9). However, further increasing the temperature to 60, 80, and 100 °C (entries 12–14) gradually declined the yields. This decrease can be attributed to undesired side reactions or possible thermal degradation of sensitive intermediates at elevated temperatures. These results underscore the critical importance of maintaining a moderate reaction temperature to achieve the maximum product yield and selectivity. Finally, the reaction time was examined to determine the minimum duration required for optimal conversion (Table 3, entries 9, 18, 19, and 20). A reaction time of 12 h afforded the highest yield of 97 % (entry 9). Shorter durations, such as 6 and 8 h, resulted in incomplete conversion, with yields of 59 % and 74 %, respectively (entries 18 and 19). Extending the reaction time to 10 h only marginally improved the yield (89 %, entry 20), confirming that 12 h is the ideal reaction time. Thus, the following were identified as the optimal reaction conditions for achieving an excellent yield of 97 %: catalyst, 8 mol% PANMGF; solvent, water; temperature, 40 °C; and reaction time, 12 h. Using these optimized parameters, we next investigated the substrate scope to explore the generality and versatility of the PANMGF in catalyzing the Knoevenagel condensation reaction. 3.5 Substrate scope in knoevenagel condensation reaction Under the optimized conditions (8 mol% PANMGF, H2O, 40 °C, 12 h), the substrate scope of the Knoevenagel condensation reaction was systematically explored to evaluate the versatility and efficiency of the PANMGF, as shown in Table 4. A diverse array of aldehydes and malononitrile derivatives was tested, which consistently afforded high yields and demonstrated excellent functional group tolerance across a range of electronic and steric substitution patterns. The overall yields were notably favorable in the substrate expansion experiments, especially for substrates with electron-withdrawing groups, which consistently achieved higher yields compared to those with electron-donating groups. This trend can be attributed to the ability of the electron-withdrawing groups to decrease the electron density on the carbonyl carbon of the aromatic aldehydes, which enhanced their electrophilicity and reactivity. For instance, substrates containing strong electron-withdrawing groups, such as trifluoromethyl (Tables 4, 3k, 3l, and 3m), nitro (Tables 4, 3o and 3p), fluorine (Tables 4, 3q, 3r, and 3s), chlorine (Tables 4, 3t and 3u), and bromine (Tables 4, 3v and 3w), exhibited significantly higher yields, corroborating this observation. Substrates like 3k (trifluoromethyl) and 3p (nitro) afforded yields of 98 % and 91 %, respectively, further reinforcing the significant impact of these substituents on reactivity. In addition, substrates containing malononitrile (Table 4, 3aa) and methyl cyanoacetate (Table 4, 3ab) with benzaldehyde afforded excellent results, with yields exceeding 95 %, further reflecting the high reactivity of these electron-deficient substrates. This observation is consistent with the well-established reactivity of electron-poor malononitrile derivatives, which readily participate in the Knoevenagel condensation. Interestingly, substrates with single electron-donating substituents, such as methyl (Tables 4, 3a, 3b, and 3c), methoxy (Tables 4, 3d, 3e, and 3f), and hydroxyl (Tables 4, 3g, 3h, and 3i) groups, also exhibit relatively high yields, with most reactions affording yields exceeding 90 %. For instance, 3b (methyl), 3d (methoxy), and 3 g (hydroxyl) produced yields of 98 %, 95 %, and 99 %, respectively. However, as the substitution pattern became more complex, particularly for disubstituted and trisubstituted electron-rich benzaldehydes (Tables 4, 3x, 3y, and 3z), a noticeable decline in the yields was observed, especially for the trisubstituted derivatives. This reduction can be attributed to the increased electron density on the carbonyl carbon, which diminishes its electrophilicity and, consequently, its reactivity toward nucleophiles. Overall, the substrate scope clearly illustrates the influence of both electronic and steric factors on the reactivity of the Knoevenagel condensation reaction. Electron-withdrawing substituents, particularly those with strong deactivating effects, enhance yields by increasing the electrophilicity of the carbonyl carbon. In contrast, electron-donating groups and sterically hindered substrates (e.g., 3j) reduce the reactivity, leading to lower yields. These findings not only highlight the consistently high yields achieved under the optimal reaction conditions, but also demonstrate the versatility and efficacy of the PANMGF as a catalyst. The substrate expansion results further underscore the robust catalytic capabilities of the PANMGF, confirming their potential for practical applications in organic synthesis. 3.6 Reaction mechanism In the mechanistic investigation of the template reaction, as illustrated in Scheme 2, a “catch–release” mechanism is invoked to explain the entire reaction process. Initially, the amide-functionalized -NH- moieties on the PANMGF capture benzaldehyde and ethyl cyanoacetate through hydrogen bonding, effectively enriching the substrates on the fiber surface and enhancing the reaction efficiency. Subsequently, the tetramethylguanidine functional groups of the PANMGF, owing to its strong basicity, abstract an active hydrogen proton from ethyl cyanoacetate, generating a highly reactive anion. This anion then undergoes a nucleophilic attack on the carbonyl carbon of the benzaldehyde, leading to the formation of an alkoxide intermediate. The intermediate, which is unstable and is accompanied by intramolecular electron transfer, tends to release a hydroxide ion that combines with a proton from the catalyst surface to form a water molecule, thereby promoting the formation and release of the target product. This step completes the “catch–release” process. The strong basicity of the guanidine-functionalized fiber underpins their catalytic efficiency. The substrate enrichment on the fiber surface further accelerates the overall reaction process. Notably, within the fiber microenvironment, a multitude of substrate molecules and guanidine functional groups coexist, which facilitate efficient and simultaneous cross-reactions rather than isolated one-to-one interactions between ethyl cyanoacetate and guanidine. The proposed mechanistic pathway depicted in Scheme 2 represents only a simplified, singular reaction event and serves as a conceptual model to illustrate the underlying catalytic process. This mechanistic pathway underscores the pivotal role of electron transfer and reactivity in driving reaction progression. The pronounced basicity of the guanidine moiety not only facilitates the formation and stabilization of reactive intermediates, but also drives the overall transformation toward high yields. Such a nuanced understanding of the mechanism provides critical insights into the catalytic performance of the functionalized fiber used in this work, paving the way for further optimizations and expansion of their potential applications in synthetic chemistry. To validate the “catch” process proposed in the mechanism outlined in Scheme 2, we performed adsorption experiments with benzaldehyde on various fiber materials, as depicted in Fig. 8. The PANF, PANPAF, PANMPAF, PANGF, and PANMGF were exposed to 40 mL of a 100-ppm benzaldehyde solution for 6 h, followed by UV absorption measurements at 245 nm. The results indicate that the unmodified PANF exhibited no significant interactions with benzaldehyde. Among the modified fibers, the PANMGF demonstrated the highest adsorption capacity, with a value of 8.2 mg/g. This observation further underscores the unique microenvironmental effect induced by guanidine functionalization on the PANMGF surface and provides direct evidence supporting the “catch” process in the proposed catalytic mechanism. 3.7 Gram-scale experiment As depicted in Scheme 3, to assess the practical applicability of the PANMGF catalyst, a gram-scale reaction was conducted. Despite scaling up the reaction by a factor of 10, the PANMGF maintained its excellent catalytic performance, achieving an isolated yield of 93 %, which is comparable to the results obtained from the small-scale reaction. This result further underscores the scalability of the PANMGF and highlights its potential for large-scale industrial applications. 3.8 Recyclability As shown in Fig. 9, the PANMGF fiber catalyst exhibited remarkable performance in the recycling experiments. In the first catalytic cycle, an impressive yield of 99.0 % was achieved. A comparison of the IR spectra of PANMGF, PANMGF-1, and PANMGF-15 ( Fig. 10) showed minimal changes in the displacement or intensity of the CN stretching vibrations after the first catalytic cycle, indicating that the guanidine groups remained largely intact and active. Even after 15 cycles, the catalyst retained a high isolated yield of 89.9 %. Meanwhile, PANMGF exhibited an incremental reduction in the intensity of the CN stretching vibration, implying the partial degradation or loss of guanidine groups, which correlated with its reduced catalytic performance. Additionally, more pronounced changes are observed in the polymer backbone region of PANMGF-15, particularly between 1000 and 1500 cm⁻¹ , which could be attributed to the adsorption of reaction products. The out-of-plane bending vibrations of the -NH- groups in the guanidine structure, observed at approximately 730.4 and 879.5 cm⁻¹ , also show moderate decline, further supporting the degradation of the guanidine functionality. The results of the repeated cycling experiments demonstrated the stability of the PANMGF and its sustained catalytic activity. These findings confirm the exceptional durability of the PANMGF, further emphasizing its potential for extended and sustainable applications. 3.9 Comparison of PANMGF with other catalytic systems Compared to other catalysts for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction, the PANMGF demonstrated superior performance. While some catalytic systems operated at lower temperatures or shorter reaction times, they failed to provide high yields and satisfactory reusability ( Table 5, entries 2 and 5). Notably, the Knoevenagel condensation catalyzed by PANMGFs offers several advantages, including the use of a green solvent, mild reaction conditions, high yields, and excellent recyclability. 4 Conclusion This work successfully synthesized the tetramethylguanidine-functionalized polyacrylonitrile fiber catalyst (PANMGF), which demonstrated remarkable catalytic efficiency in the Knoevenagel condensation reaction. Under mild reaction conditions of 40 °C in an aqueous medium for 12 h, the PANMGF afforded an excellent yield of 97 %. The catalyst exhibited a broad substrate scope across 28 different substrates, delivering consistently high yields of over 90 % for a diverse range of benzaldehyde derivatives with both electron-withdrawing and electron-donating substituents. Additionally, the PANMGF facilitated reactions with active methylene substrates, such as ethyl cyanoacetate and malononitrile, providing yields of 97 % and 98 %, respectively. Recycling experiments confirmed the stability and reusability of the PANMGF, which maintained a yield of 91.1 % even after 14 cycles, demonstrating its durability. Furthermore, gram-scale reactions achieved a high separation yield of 93.6 %, highlighting their potential for industrial-scale applications. Overall, the PANMGF demonstrates both outstanding catalytic performance and sustainability, presenting an economically viable option in green chemistry. Future research may focus on optimizing its properties further and exploring its applications in a wider range of organic transformations. coredata.dc:description: This work presents a novel and recyclable tetramethylguanidine-modified polyacrylonitrile fiber catalyst (PANMGF), specifically designed for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction, which is a crucial method in organic synthesis for CC bond formation. The PANMGF was characterized through Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), elemental analysis (EA), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and mechanical performance analysis. These results collectively confirmed the successful grafting of dimethylcyanamide as a guanidine precursor, which was subsequently converted into tetramethylguanidine functionalities on the PANMGF. Under mild conditions of 40 °C with H2O as the solvent for a 12-hour reaction, the PANMGF exhibited superior catalytic performance, with a yield of 97 %. A thorough investigation of various benzaldehyde substrates revealed yields exceeding 90 % for both electron-withdrawing and electron-donating derivatives. These results demonstrate the remarkable substrate versatility and broad applicability of this catalyst. Moreover, when applied to other active methylene substrates, such as methyl cyanoacetate and malononitrile, the PANMGF achieved yields of 97 % and 98 %, respectively. These results collectively underscore its broad substrate scope across 28 different substrates and exceptional stability, which maintained a yield of 91.1 % even after 14 cycles, with an 89.9 % yield observed in the 15th cycle. Additionally, gram-scale experiments yielded a high separation efficiency of 93.6 %, further reinforcing the significant potential of PANMGF for practical applications in sustainable organic synthesis.
